S2.T1.caption: Table 1. The list of notations used in this work.
S2.T1.table:
Notations Description
t𝑡t The t𝑡tth global training round
M𝑀M Total number of clients
DMksubscript𝐷subscript𝑀𝑘D_{M_{k}} Metadata from client k𝑘k
DMsubscript𝐷𝑀D_{M} The union of metadata from all clients
Ak[j]subscriptsuperscript𝐴delimited-[]𝑗𝑘A^{[j]}_{k} Activation maps from client k𝑘k at level j𝑗j
MGsubscript𝑀𝐺M_{G} The global model
MCksubscript𝑀subscript𝐶𝑘M_{C_{k}} The k𝑘kth client model
MC​O​Msubscript𝑀𝐶𝑂𝑀M_{COM} The composed model
𝑾Gsubscript𝑾𝐺\bm{W}_{G} Weights of the global model
𝑾Gusuperscriptsubscript𝑾𝐺𝑢\bm{W}_{G}^{u} Weights of upper part of the global model
𝑾Glsuperscriptsubscript𝑾𝐺𝑙\bm{W}_{G}^{l} Weights of lower part of the global model
𝑾Cksubscript𝑾subscript𝐶𝑘\bm{W}_{C_{k}} Weights of the client model k𝑘k
𝑾Susuperscriptsubscript𝑾𝑆𝑢\bm{W}_{S}^{u} Weights of upper part of the updated global model
references: The global CNN model in our proposed method is trained on both the server side and the client side. The lower part of the model is trained in the standard federated average approach, with locally updated models being aggregated on the server side for updating the lower part. The upper part of the model is trained entirely on the server side, using the activation maps produced and uploaded by the clients. The list of the notations used in this section are presented in Table 1.

S4.T2.caption: Table 2. The dimension of the activation maps at different levels in the global CNN model (WRN-40-1). For an image input, the higher the level of the model, the lower resolutions of the activation map.

references: The Wide Residual Networks (WRN) (Zagoruyko and Komodakis, 2016) is used as the global CNN model. The global model MGsubscript𝑀𝐺M_{G} is built on a WRN with a depth of 40 and width of 1 (WRN-40-1). The layers of WRN-40-1 are hierarchically organized into 3 groups as discussed in Section 3.1. The dimension of activation maps extracted at different level j𝑗j of the WRN-40-1 is shown in Table 2.

S4.T3.caption: Table 3. Comparison of the performance of DC​O​Msubscript𝐷𝐶𝑂𝑀D_{COM} with metadata selection and without metadata selection (full activation maps to train on) on the CIFAR-10 image classification task. In metadata selection, each client selects 40 activation maps to form the metadata, uniformly distributed across classes. This is 1.6% of total activation maps available over the entire training set. The option without selection has no clusters.

references: To evaluate the effect of using metadata selection, we use another baseline produced by using the entire set of activation maps from the whole training set on the composed model DC​O​Msubscript𝐷𝐶𝑂𝑀D_{COM} (full metadata). This baseline collects all the activation maps produced by the clients to form DMsubscript𝐷𝑀D_{M}. Table 3 compares our proposed metadata selection to the baseline of using the entire set of metadata (activation maps). When the upper part of MC​O​Msubscript𝑀𝐶𝑂𝑀M_{COM} is updated on the entire activation maps without selection (50000 in total), DC​O​Msubscript𝐷𝐶𝑂𝑀D_{COM} achieves a higher test accuracy of 70.03%. In contrast, the test accuracy of MC​O​Msubscript𝑀𝐶𝑂𝑀M_{COM} is just 48.47% due to DMsubscript𝐷𝑀D_{M} being reduced to containing just 800 activation maps selected by our proposed clustering approach. A drop in accuracy is understandable due to reduced training data. We aim to narrow this performance gap by evaluating different levels in the network for extracting activation maps.

S4.T4.caption: Table 4. Comparison among centralized training, Federated Average (FedAvg) and our FL approach with selected metadata. All use WRN-40-1 as the global model. The centralized version trains the model using the entire training data on a single machine, thus achieving the best performance. The FedAvg forms another strong baseline by assuming full client participation in each round. In our approach, we show the performance of the composed model trained on full activation maps and selected activation maps with on our clustering based selection (PCA+K-means). Our FL approach using split learning and metadata training outperforms the FedAvg baseline if all activation maps from either level G​1𝐺1G1 or G​2𝐺2G2 are used. With respect to using the selected metadata, we show that using selected metadata from level G​3𝐺3G3 produces a global model with a minimal performance drop. Missing values indicate not applicable settings.

references: To justify this hypothesis, we further reduce the number of learnable parameters in the upper part by predefining a higher j𝑗j level. Table 4 shows our experiment for using metadata from all three levels. In addition to the baseline without using metadata selection described in Section 4.2, we further include a baseline where the global model is trained on the entire CIFAR-10 training set in a centralized manner and a FedAvg  (McMahan et al., 2017) baseline assuming full client participation.
